div.head:
Embleme 16. Of the Secrets of Nature.
One Lyon hath wings, the other none.

lg.l: The Lyon prince of beasts in might and sway
Fights without fear, and scornesscorns to runne away:
Give him a Spouse with wings of his owne race,
To mount him with herselfe from place to place;
But hee immoved stands, and nulls her force,
By Embleme to demonstrate Natures course.

div.head: Discourse 16.
div.ab:
It is a thing knowne by experience that a Lyon excells other animalls not
soe much in bignesse and strength of body, as generosity: if hee be seen in-
hunting, being ashamdashamed to runne away, hee releasethreleases himselfe by degrees,
if hee be oppressd by a multitude: being removed from the view of the-
hunters, hee makes hast away, thinking it a dishonourdishonor to be excusdexcused by ab
sconding: hee desires a wood in flight, which hee usethuses, when anything
pursues: his bones are solid and not at all empty, which are sayd to be
soe hard, that being shakdshaked together they yeild fire as out of a Steel and-
flint. Hee fears fire above all things. Hee seems to derive his substance
from the nature of the Sunne, for in force and heat hee excells other-
animalls, as the Sunne doth the Starrs: Besides hee is allways beheld with
fiery and open eyes, as the Sunne beholds the earth with an open and-
fiery eye: a LionesseLioness fighting for her whelps fixethfixes her eyes upon the-
ground, that Shee may not be afrayd of the hunters Staffs and Spears.-
where a Lyon perceives the coition of a Leopard, hee takes revenge-
upon the Lionesse for adultery, and inflicts severe punnishment;-
The Lionesse therefore washethwashes away the offenceoffense and scent in a river,-
or being conscious of the trespassetrespass doth allso accompany the adulterer-
flying for fear of the make: Which wonderfull nature of this beast the
Philosophers contemplating, have produced severall allegoryes of the
Lyon, as it were hieroglyphicall writings testifying of their secret-
worke, observing the Lyon to be a constant, firme animall, without-
deceiptdeceit and suspicion, they assimilated the better part of their Phi
losophicall composition to him: for as hee flyes not, soeso neither this:-
hee with solid bones, soeso this fixed and not to be overcome: and as-
the Lionesse is not allways innocent and free from adultery, soeso-
is neither Luna nor Mercury without some blemish, but is joyned
by the ignorant sometimes to this, sometimes to that matter, where
by an adulterous conjunction of things discrepant and different in
nature rather than true matrimony is established: for the products
of a Leopard and Lionesse have noe specious and comely mains-
about the necke and Shoulders; with which ensigneensign those generated
by the Lyon are alone adorned. The Philosophicall Lionesse must
therefore be joyned to her proper mate or male, and a genuine-
and generous whelp will from theme Spring, which may easily
be knowne by his paw. But the Lionesse must not be any or-
what you pledge, but winged, which may be able to fight and
contest with the Lyon, depending upon the SwiftnesseSwiftness of her-
plumes, lest (to witt) Shee Should be oppressed by his extraordi
nary wrath, but to thinke upon escape, if at any time hee fall
into fury without cause, for hee when hee stops her flying-

is incited with greater love toward her, freindship being made after discord.-
But you will say who ever saw a Lionesse with wings, or what can the plumes
of a Lionesse avayle? There is a deep valley near the mountaine CythærenCytheran,
in which are seen none but flying Lionesse, and at the top of the same-
mountaine resorts a red Lyon of that kind, which Hercules killed. The-
Lyon therefore must be taken, and brought into the valley, and forthwith
coupled to the winged Lionesse: Shee allso will easily suffer herselfe to
be overcome, as like by like: afterwards they must be both advanced
out of the sayd valley to the top of the mountaine, and henceforth they
will never desert one another, but allwayes remaine together in inviolable
amity: The taking of Lyons. I confesseconfess, is not easy, but obnoxious to many-
dangers, neverthelesse it must be attempted: a Lyon feeds not with the-
Lionesse, but strayesstrays apart, as story relates, therefore they are to be found and
hunted severally: But if the Lyons whelps be obtaind in their infancy, when
they first begin to goe, which is at two moneths age, and be joyned, as afore
sayd, being come to good growth and stature, the thing will be free from-
any danger. Moreover they breed in the Spring time, which must be well
observed: but Lyons after whelping using crosse and winding wayes, to
prævent the discovery of their denneden, therefore must they be sought and
their whelps taken away very great diligence and care. . . .
